function.name: submission_eval
function.description: This function is used to evaluate the public submission to the consultation. Each parameter property is a question that you must respond to after carefully reading the description.

substantive_submission.description: Does the submission provide a substantive response to the consultation (True or False)? Substantive submissions are those that provide a detailed or well reasoned response to the consultation. Screenshots of memes or other pre-existing content are not considered substantive. Submissions relying on conspiracy theories are not considered substantive. A submission expressing purely personal opinion is not considered substantive. Consider the supplementary materials and determine if the submission answers substantively answers the issues, concerns and questions raised in the consultation.

responder_category.description: One aspect of the research is looking how different categories of responders respond to the consultation. Based on the response (especially the name of the responder - e.g. if it is a company or group), please select the category that best describes the responder. Options are: 1. Individual 2. Political (e.g. Government agencie or politician or political part) 3. Digital Platform (e.g. Meta, Microsoft, Google, etc.) 4. Civil Society (e.g. NGO, advocacy group, etc.) 5. Academic 6. News (e.g. a news company such as News Corp, ABC or Nine News, or a industry association representing news organisations such as Australian Press Council or Commerical Radio Australia or FreeTV) 7. Other (please specify). Only return the category that best describes the responder. E.g. for a submission from the UTS Centre for Media Transition, you would return: 'Academic'.

support.description: Overall, considering the whole of the submission, does the submission support, oppose, or have a neutral stance towards the proposed laws? Make sure you truly understand the submissions position, some confusion may arise where the submission is supporting another submission, but this does not mean the submission is in support of the proposed changes. If you are unsure, such as in this situation, respond with 'unsure'. (return only one of the following options: 'support', 'oppose', 'neutral', 'unsure')

motivations.description:
Number the top 3 motivations or concerns underpinning the submission's view point. Keep each short and brief (under 5 words). E.g.

['Privacy', 'Freedom of speech', 'Complexity']

If only one or two key motivations, return only these one or two.

regulation.description: Does this submission make any comment on the form of regulation provided by the Bill (e.g. does the submission comment on the practicality, or desirability of codes of practice, e.g. co-regulation, or the specific merits of the use of legislation in regulating misinformation or disinformation, or do that make specific comments as to the preferability of no regulation)? If so, please provide a brief summary of the comment, and there reasoning behind their belief. If no comment on this aspect, return 'No comment'.

perceived_impact.description: How does the submitter perceive the impact of the proposed laws on combating misinformation and disinformation? What impact do they foresee on the broader digital ecosystem, including social media platforms, content creators, and the general public? If no comment on this aspect, return 'No comment'.

regulator_trust.description: Does the submission express trust or skepticism towards the ACMA's ability to impartially and effectively use the new powers? Are there any suggestions for ensuring accountability and oversight? If no comment on this aspect, return 'No comment'.
